author: bridge-bot
content:
<gakonst> IMO multi dim pricing is premature optimization atm, esp given mempool ordering rules becoming harder to optimize over N vs 1

I'd focus all resources on proposing a few gas schedules and benchmarking their cputime/gas, ideally building up to a tool similar To Daniel's work in this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.07220

author: bridge-bot

author: bridge-bot
content: <shemnon> Most of the multi-dim discussions have been in calldata repricing and block-level access list, via refunds.  Variable gas prices in the EVM haven't had serious discussion, so most of the dimensions won't impact block building as the tx evals will be stable or result in eth refunds rathter than gas refunds inside the TX.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<thogard> re: **@gakonst**
> IMO multi dim pricing is premature optimization atm, esp given mempool ordering rules becoming harder to optimize over N vs 1

I'd focus all resources on proposing a few gas schedules and benchmarking their cputime/gas, ideally building up to a tool similar To Daniel's work in this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.07220
Can you elaborate on what you mean by 'mempool ordering rules becoming harder to optimize over N vs 1'? Are you referring to the resource usage of having to sort all the txs in the local mempool (resource usage being superlinear with number of txs), DDoS mitigations (spam reduction / deduplication), or something else?

author: _shemnon
content:
A couple of other discussion points:
* what are we targeting for Glamsterdam?
* Should we get a standard "gas schedule" configuration, containing config params, values, algorithm switches, etc. that clients should use.
  * This may be useful for native rollup around fork transitions for when the proven block is on the old fork

author: funnygiulio
content: I think dim calldata pricing for glamsterdam is premature

author: funnygiulio
content: I think at Glamsterdam the main focus will (just talking about scaling because I assume this channel still optimizes for it) be full EIP-4444 (1-year window or less) and just simple re-repricings of potentially overpriced opcodes like we are doing for calldata pricing and modexp in fusaka

author: funnygiulio
content: Personally, I am not exactly a fan of dim pricing because I think it gives really diminishing returns that migth be relevant in rare exoteric situations and adds significant complexity for very little reward, cool on paper but it is not a great UX-leap. happy to be proven wrong here btw

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> ah this has a tg

author: bridge-bot
content:
<notnotstorm_p> re: **@evm_pricing_bot**
> <funnygiulio> [reply]: I think dim calldata pricing for glamsterdam is premature
I think this depends on how much we are bottlenecked on bandwidth

- scenario 1: the max block bytesize is small enough relative to the gas limit that it frequently gets reached
- scenario 2: the max block bytesize is large enough relative to the gas limit that it almost never gets reached

vitalik raised a good point that fee markets revert to first price auctions in scenario 1. this harms ux for landing txs onchain

so whether we'll want calldata dim depends on the ratio (max block bytesize):(gas limit). max block bytesize is also a pretty inflexible constraint based on validator bandwidth

author: bridge-bot
content: <pgarimidi> if multidim pricing is implemented I think you want the user ux to look the same as today in terms of just bidding a max willingness to pay and a priority fee. you just change the priority fee to always be pay as bid instead of metered by gas usage, there’s pretty little reason to make the user submit an n-dimensional bid

author: sky.cactus
content: I wonder if it would be possible to have upcoming block builders commit to a min priority fee they will accept in some way.  Since most blocks aren't full, builders include any transaction that meets their min priority fee requirement.

author: sky.cactus
content: I guess one problem here is that the min priority fee *shouldn't* actually be static, it should be a function of block fullness (the fuller the block, the higher the min priority fee to account for the risk of loss due to block not propagating fast enough).

author: sky.cactus
content: If there was a way to telegraph though, then we wouldn't even have to ask users for priority fees, and they could be multidimensional and automatically handled by the client based on upcoming builder telegraphs.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@notnotstorm_p**
> I think this depends on how much we are bottlenecked on bandwidth

- scenario 1: the max block bytesize is small enough relative to the gas limit that it frequently gets reached
- scenario 2: the max block bytesize is large enough relative to the gas limit that it almost never gets reached

vitalik raised a good point that fee markets revert to first price auctions in scenario 1. this harms ux for landing txs onchain

so whether we'll want calldata dim depends on the ratio (max block bytesize):(gas limit). max block bytesize is also a pretty inflexible constraint based on validator bandwidth
premature != should never happen.

I am saying I do not see an immediate need for it
